image.altText: Map of temperatures anomalies in southern parts of South America

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Scientists in disbelief as temperatures soar to 37C in South America in the middle of winter

image.altText: Neil Gaughan at a Senate Committee.

image.altText: A house cordoned off with police tape.

items.synopsis: Judith Ann Venn had "reached the end of the road", when she fed her husband his "favourite" vegetable soup, which was laced with 50 pills of his prescription medication.

title.children: 69yo woman jailed for killing abusive husband with spiked vegetable soup

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his friendship with a senior PwC partner with whom he discussed a contract for the consulting firm.

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner rubbishes claims he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie

items.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman on bail for her alleged role in a 2021 murder has asked the Supreme Court to send her back to prison because of the "daily battle just trying to find suitable accommodation".

title.children: Woman on bail unable to find housing asks court to send her back to jail, judge agrees

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege Mr Trump conspired to defraud the US by preventing Congress from certifying Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.

title.children: Donald Trump pleads not guilty to 2020 election interference

image.altText: A team of people dressed in red and white walk and wave through a stadium, with a Canadian flag.

title.children: Canadian province shelves plans to bid for 2030 Commonwealth Games due to costs

image.altText: woman smiling

items.synopsis: The parents of a 23-year-old woman who died from meningococcal B have praised today's decision to make the vaccine free and available in routine child and teen immunisation in Queensland.

title.children: It's Bella's legacy, family says, as Queensland makes meningococcal B vaccine free for children

image.altText: Aerial photo of Groote Eylandt coast line.

items.synopsis: Police say spears, crossbows and machetes have been used in the violence which involved up to 150 people on the island in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: Trio hospitalised after violent outbreak on tropical NT island

image.altText: Blue and white police tape in front of traffic accident scene

items.synopsis: Police have declared a crime scene after a person was found dead following a camper trailer fire on the Scenic Rim, west of Brisbane, this morning.

title.children: Person found dead, known resident missing after fire destroys camper trailer near Boonah

image.altText: The Ares 1-X test rocket lifts off from Kennedy Space Centre

items.synopsis: Australia's space industry is warning the sector is "in limbo" and facing an uncertain future after the axing of several key space programs.

title.children: Australia's space industry 'in limbo' after key programs axed

image.altText: A huge 1970s apartment building, with white balconies, many of which feature lush gardens

items.synopsis: Vienna is often pointed to as a Western city that is getting its housing strategy right. So how do they do it?

title.children: In Vienna, most people live in social housing. Here's how it works

items.synopsis: Less than half of Australian parents and guardians are open with their kids about consent and their body. It could be part of the reason why child sex abuse victims stay silent.

image.altText: Megan Krakouer wears a shirt marking the 50th anniversary of the tent embassy

title.children: 'Really difficult decision': Prominent campaigner against Voice set to vote yes after changing mind

image.altText: Keith Urban and Nicole Kidman

items.synopsis: Grammy award-winning country music star Keith Urban will be inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame, one of songwriting's highest honours.

title.children: From Australia to the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame. Keith Urban's journey was never easy

image.altText: Nigerian players celebrate

items.synopsis: The African and Caribbean nations have qualified for the Women's World Cup knock-outs, but their success belies the challenges they've been battling back home.

title.children: 'Pay them!': Nigeria, Jamaica, South Africa success stories highlight World Cup inequalities

image.altText: aerial of wind farm

items.synopsis: A group of traditional owners is taking its fight to Canberra in a last-ditch effort to stop the $1 billion Chalumbin Wind Farm from being built adjacent to World Heritage-protected rainforests in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Traditional owners to take fight to Canberra over wind farm to be built near protected rainforests

image.altText: A black electric vehicle hooked up to a Tesla charging station

items.synopsis: Electric Vehicle Council finds Australia's transition is lagging behind countries including China and Thailand due to "outdated" regulations.

title.children: EV strategy has to accelerate, says report, as Australia falls behind

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This was another question put to Treasury officials during the cost of living committee hearing by Senator Jane Hume. Treasury's forecast for GDP (or economic growth) in the May budget was 3.25% for the 2022-23 financial year, and Senator Hume asked if that was going to be achieved. Ineke Redmond from Treasury said they still needed to compile and review data to form a more thorough assessment, but said developments including population growth (including migration) could see an increase in GDP, if not equalling that forecast, despite a slightly sharp fall in consumption because of inflation and interest rates. Treasury's Luke Yeaman also reiterated Ms Redmond's comments and said overall the economy was tracking "quite close" to its growth forecasts. Mr Yeaman said while he wouldn't attribute a number to economic growth right now, the economy was developing broadly in line with its expectations as forecast in the budget. (For what it's worth, the RBA's just released economic outlook within its August Statement on Monetary Policy shows the central bank is now expecting a year-average GDP growth to be 3% for the 2022-23 financial year .)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Treasury's economic growth forecast on track?

3.25% for the 2022-23 financial year
, and Senator Hume asked if that was going to be achieved.
Ineke Redmond from Treasury
said they still needed to compile and review data to form a more thorough assessment, but said developments including population growth (including migration)
could see an increase in GDP, if not equalling that forecast,
despite a slightly sharp fall in consumption because of inflation and interest rates.
Treasury's

also reiterated Ms Redmond's comments and said overall the economy was tracking "quite close" to its growth forecasts.

economy was developing broadly in line with its expectations as forecast in the budget
(For what it's worth, the RBA's just released economic outlook within its August Statement on Monetary Policy shows the central bank is now expecting a year-average
GDP growth to be 3% for the 2022-23 financial year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A brief hello from me — I've spent the morning listening to the Select Committee on the Cost of Living, where senators were asking Treasury officials about all things inflation and living cost pressures (as the name might suggest). Committee member senator Karen Grogan asked Treasury's Luke Yeaman whether the federal budget handed down in May was inflationary. Mr Yeaman explained that the economy had been seeing a substantial fiscal contraction, which had helped to take the pressure off inflation, and the budget contained measures that helped to reduce inflation (like rent, childcare and electricity bill assistance). He said Treasury's overall sense was that the budget was not adding to inflation, and that had also been the general reaction from financial markets. This line of questioning was also picked up by the committee chair, senator Jane Hume, who asked if the budget was "deflationary". Mr Yeaman responded that the budget was "broadly neutral" and reiterated that there was a substantial contraction and explained that while fiscal policy did have some lagging elements that took time to flow through, there were contractionary elements that were also coming through to keep inflation lower. He again explained that electricity prices, childcare and Commonwealth rental assistance were having direct downwards impacts while inflation and CPI was high. He said he understood the comments around the budget, but maintained that Treasury's stance was that the budget was helping bring inflation down. (I also wrote about what impact the federal budget could have on interest rates and inflation after it was handed down — you can have a read of that below.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury officials maintain that federal budget not adding to inflation

featuredLink.title: Budget heightens risk for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates 'at least once' in coming months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two hours into the local session, and the ASX 200 remains very near the flatline — at last check just two points lower. That's despite a good showing by the energy sector, after oil prices rallied overnight. Energy names dominate the best performing stocks, alongside Domino's Pizza (+2.8%) and Tabcorp (+2.4%). And on the flipside Block (-10.5%) and ResMed (-10.2%) continue to lag. In response to the ACCC decision to block a $4.9 billion takeover deal, ANZ shares are up 0.6 per cent, roughly in line with gains for some of the other banks, while Suncorp shares have pared early losses to be down 0.3 per cent. And the Australian dollar has risen modestly, up 0.4 per cent to around 65.8 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy leading ASX, Aussie dollar higher
